title: Changes in the Structure of Wages During the 1980's:  An Evaluation     of Alternative Explanations
author: John Bound, George E. Johnson
target_context: Using 1979 and 1987 Current Population Survey data for U.S. nonagricultural employees aged 18–64, the paper analyzes group-level (education × experience × sex) changes in log hourly wages across 17 industries to explain large 1979–87 shifts: rising returns to schooling, greater experience differentials among lower-educated workers, and a narrower gender gap. The authors combine cross-sectional wage regressions, industry employment-change measures, and Oaxaca-style decompositions to evaluate explanations tied to product-demand/trade shocks, within-industry rent changes, technological bias, and changes in unobserved labor quality.

Units are workers and occupations across the United States. The analysis situates observed wage and employment polarization in a setting of falling computer prices, rising computerization and outsourcing, and changing institutions (minimum wage and unions) that altered labor demand by task.

The authors combine cross-sectional wage regressions, industry employment-change measures, and Oaxaca-style decompositions to evaluate explanations tied to product-demand/trade shocks, within-industry rent changes, technological bias, and changes in unobserved labor quality.

title: Rational Addictive Behavior and Cigarette Smoking
author: Frank J. Chaloupka
target_context: This paper analyzes individual-level cigarette demand in the United States using NHANES II survey data collected 1976–1980 (adults up to age 74). It exploits cross-state and local variation in cigarette prices and excise taxes (including nearest-border prices) together with respondents' recalled past, current, and peak smoking to estimate dynamic demand and an addictive stock. The institutional setting highlights tax-driven price variation and health-policy relevance for current, former, and ever smokers.

title: Changes in Relative Wages, 1963-1987: Supply and Demand Factors
author: Lawrence F. Katz, Kevin M. Murphy
target_context: Analyzes U.S. wage-structure changes from 1963–1987 using 25 consecutive March CPS supplements. Units are demographic labor groups (sex × education × experience, aggregated into 320/64 cells) with full-time weekly wages and total hours in efficiency units. The paper evaluates how shifts in relative supplies (education cohorts, age structure, female labor supply) and demand shifts — both within- and between-industry/occupation (skill-biased technology, product demand, trade) — generated movements in the college premium, experience returns, gender gaps, and within-group inequality.

title: Does Head Start Make a Difference?
author: Janet Currie, Duncan Thomas
target_context: This paper uses the US National Longitudinal Survey of Youth Child–Mother data (children of the 1979 NLSY cohort, surveyed in 1986–1990) to estimate effects of participation in the federal Head Start preschool program on children’s cognitive scores, grade repetition, immunizations, and height, and on longer‑run outcomes for women. Units are children (and mothers with sister comparisons); the sample is national with oversamples of African‑Americans and Hispanics. Identification relies on within‑family comparisons to address time‑invariant family confounders.

title: Trade Policy, Exchange Rates and Growth
author: Sebastian Edwards
target_context: This triplet concerns Latin American case studies of trade liberalization and their sector-level effects: it focuses on manufacturing‑sector labor productivity responses to reduced tariffs and non‑tariff barriers. The paper reports that Chilean manufacturing labor productivity rose an average 13.4% annually between 1978 and 1981, while Mexico saw more modest post‑reform gains (an index rising from 92.7 to 105.1 and a reported 2.3% annual increase excluding maquiladoras). The institutional setting is trade reforms that increased foreign competition.

title: Saving Babies: The Efficacy and Cost of Recent Expansions of Medicaid   Eligibility for Pregnant Women
author: Janet Currie, Jonathan Gruber
target_context: This paper studies US Medicaid eligibility expansions for pregnant women across 49 states (plus DC) during 1979–1990. Units include state-year aggregates (Vital Statistics infant outcomes) and individual women aged 15–44 (CPS, NLSY). It exploits cross-state, over-time variation from targeted AFDC-linked expansions in the early 1980s and broader income-based expansions (1987–1990, e.g. 133%–185% FPL) to assess effects on low birthweight, infant mortality, Medicaid take-up, service use, and program expenditures.

title: Saving Babies: The Efficacy and Cost of Recent Expansions of Medicaid   Eligibility for Pregnant Women
author: Janet Currie, Jonathan Gruber
target_context: This triplet uses state-year panel data across 49 states plus DC (1979–1990) on Medicaid payments reported to HCFA—physician, clinic, and inpatient/outpatient hospital expenditures for non-disabled children and non-disabled/non-elderly adults—normalized by each state's 15–44 female population. The authors regress annual per-woman Medicaid expenditures on simulated state Medicaid eligibility for pregnant women (disaggregating targeted vs. broad expansions), including state and year fixed effects (Arizona excluded). Estimates report about $232 per additional eligible woman overall and $449 per woman for targeted expansions.

title: Sticky Prices: New Evidence from Retail Catalogs
author: Anil K. Kashyap
target_context: This paper analyzes semiannual catalog list prices for twelve staple retail goods sold by three U.S. mail-order firms (L.L. Bean, Orvis, REI) from 1953–1987 (with some items shorter), using item-by-item price series as the unit of observation. The institutional setting is U.S. mail-order retailing where firms publish Spring/Fall catalogs—prices are typically fixed six months—and includes a high-inflation episode (≈1968–1982). The study focuses on nominal price change frequency, size, and synchronization across goods, controlling for CPI, monetary base, competitor prices, and cost proxies.

target_context: This paper studies the causal effect of reductions in collectively-bargained standard weekly hours in (West) Germany, primarily 1984–1989 with additional analysis for 1990–1994, exploiting monthly industry‑level panel data on 201 manufacturing industries and individual-level German Socio‑Economic Panel data on full‑time workers. The institutional setting is industry-level union bargaining (notably IG Metall) that implemented stepwise cuts in standard hours, overtime premia, and greater hours flexibility; outcomes examined include employment, hours per worker, worker‑hours, and wage bills.

question:
# Role
You are an expert economist.

# Task
You are given examples in which the same or comparable treatment–outcome pair is observed across multiple contexts, potentially with different causal signs.
Predict the most likely sign for the treatment–outcome pair in the target context.

# Sign Definitions
- '+': The treatment increases the outcome (positive and statistically significant effect).
- '-': The treatment decreases the outcome (negative and statistically significant effect).
- 'None': No statistically significant effect.
- 'mixed': The effect varies across subgroups or specifications.

# Reference Examples
## Example 1
Treatment: Reduction in standard hours
Outcome: Actual hours worked
Context: Using the German Socio-Economic Panel (1984–1989) for West Germany, this estimate focuses on Arbeiter (hourly workers) in manufacturing (person–job spells). The paper exploits within-job temporal variation from industry-level union‑negotiated reductions in standard weekly hours (mid‑1980s onward) and estimates person–job fixed-effects panel regressions (with IV robustness) to relate reductions in agreed standard hours to changes in actual weekly hours.
Sign: -

## Example 2
Treatment: Reduction in standard hours
Outcome: Straight-time hourly wage
Context: Using German Socio-Economic Panel data 1984–1989, this paper studies individual workers (person-job spells) in West Germany—particularly Arbeiter (hourly) and Angestellten (salaried) in manufacturing, construction and services—during union-negotiated stepwise reductions in industry-level standard weekly hours (starting in 1985, notably metalworking/printing). The institutional setting features collective bargaining, overtime premiums, flexibility clauses, and industry-level wage negotiations; the paper exploits within-job temporal variation across industries to estimate effects of standard-hours reductions on actual hours and straight-time hourly wages.
Sign: +


# Target Context
This paper studies the causal effect of reductions in collectively-bargained standard weekly hours in (West) Germany, primarily 1984–1989 with additional analysis for 1990–1994, exploiting monthly industry‑level panel data on 201 manufacturing industries and individual-level German Socio‑Economic Panel data on full‑time workers. The institutional setting is industry-level union bargaining (notably IG Metall) that implemented stepwise cuts in standard hours, overtime premia, and greater hours flexibility; outcomes examined include employment, hours per worker, worker‑hours, and wage bills.

# Target Treatment–Outcome Pair
Treatment: Reduction in standard hours
Outcome: Worker-hours (hourly-paid workers)

# Output Format
Respond with a JSON object containing:
- predicted_sign: "+", "-", "None", or "mixed"
- reasoning: A concise explanation of your reasoning

title: Implications of Skill-Biased Technological Change: International Evidence
author: Eli Berman, John Bound, Stephen Machin
target_context: This triplet refers specifically to manufacturing labor markets in developed OECD countries (a ten-country sample) over roughly 1970–1990 with focal windows like 1979–87 (US) and 1979–90 (UK). The unit of observation is industry- and plant-level employment shares (nonproduction = skilled vs production = unskilled) using UN industrial statistics, U.S. Census/ASM and worker–establishment matched data. The paper links pervasive, microprocessor‑related skill‑biased technological change to within‑industry increases in the proportion of skilled (nonproduction) workers, concentrated in machinery (& computers), electrical machinery, and printing & publishing.

title: Implications of Skill-Biased Technological Change: International Evidence

title: Do After-Tax Returns Affect Mutual Fund Inflows?
author: Daniel Bergstresser, James Poterba
target_context: This paper studies U.S. domestic equity mutual funds using fund-year data primarily from 1993–1998 (≈5,866 fund-years), with a smaller 1994–1998 sample for gross inflow/outflow analysis and an institutional-fund subsample. Units are individual mutual funds; data come from Morningstar and SEC filings. The institutional setting is the U.S. personal income tax system: authors construct after-tax (buy-and-hold) returns for hypothetical upper-income investors (assumed dividend/short-term tax 31%, long-term gains 20%, 10% effective accrual tax on unrealized gains) and analyze how after-tax returns and capital-gains overhangs predict fund inflows and redemptions.

title: Thirty Years of Current Account Imbalances, Current Account Reversals and Sudden Stops
author: Sebastian Edwards
target_context: Using annual country-year data for 157 countries over 1970–2001, this paper studies current-account imbalances, large deficit “reversals,” and “sudden stops.” The unit of observation is the country-year across six regions (industrial, Latin America/Caribbean, Asia, Africa, MENA, Eastern Europe). Analyses relate lagged external debt, reserves, short-term debt, and credit growth to reversal probability and estimate reversal impacts on GDP growth, contextualized by 1970s oil shocks, the 1980s debt crisis, 1990s currency crises, IMF programs, and varying exchange-rate/dollarization regimes.

title: The Impact of Nearly Universal Insurance Coverage on Health Care Utilization and Health: Evidence from Medicare
author: David Card, Carlos Dobkin, Nicole Maestas
target_context: This paper analyzes U.S. microdata—pooled NHIS (1992–2001) and BRFSS (1998–2002) surveys, state hospital discharge records (California and Florida, 1995–1999/2000), and national death files—to study individuals and hospital admissions around the Medicare eligibility cutoff. Exploiting the institutional rule that most people become eligible for Medicare at age 65 (Part A/B availability subject to work-history rules), the authors estimate how the near-universal jump in coverage at 65 affects access, utilization, procedures, and self-reported and mortality outcomes for people just below and above 65.

title: From Education to Democracy?
author: Daron Acemoglu, Simon Johnson, James A. Robinson, Pierre Yared
target_context: This triplet is estimated using the country-level panel (about 108 countries) over 1965–2000 at five-year intervals. target_context: This paper uses a laboratory experiment (University of Pittsburgh, 2005) with 80 undergraduate subjects arranged in 20 groups of four (two men, two women). target_context: This paper exploits a discontinuity generated by how the U.S. Office of Economic Opportunity (OEO) launched Head Start in 1965 by providing grant-writing assistance to the 300 poorest 1960 counties. title: Disease and Development: The Effect of Life Expectancy on Economic Growth
author: Daron Acemoglu, Simon Johnson
target_context: This cross-country study analyzes country-level effects of the mid-20th-century “international epidemiological transition” (primarily 1940–1980) across about 59 countries (decadal country-year observations). The unit is the country; outcomes include life expectancy, population, total births, GDP and GDP per capita. Identification exploits exogenous timing of global health interventions (e.g., antibiotics, DDT, WHO campaigns) interacted with pre-1940 disease-specific mortality rates. The core institutional background is the global diffusion of medical and public-health technologies after WWII and resulting differential mortality declines by baseline disease burden.

title: Big Business Stability and Economic Growth: Is What's Good for General Motors Good for America?
author: Kathy Fogel, Randall Morck, Bernard Yeung
target_context: This paper studies the relationship between stability of the largest firms/business groups and long-run national economic growth across 44 countries. title: Temporary Investment Tax Incentives: Theory with Evidence from Bonus Depreciation

title: The Spike at Benefit Exhaustion: Leaving the Unemployment System or Starting a New Job?
author: David Card, Raj Chetty, Andrea Weber
target_context: Using Austrian social security administrative records for involuntary job losses from 1981–2001, the paper analyzes about 92,969 individuals aged 20–50 to study exit hazards around unemployment insurance (UI) benefit exhaustion. Austria’s UI rules provide 20 or 30 weeks of benefits depending on months worked in the prior five years (36-month threshold), alongside severance pay rules and means-tested post-exhaustion assistance. The analysis contrasts registered-unemployment duration and time-to-next-job (including recalls) to assess whether spikes at benefit expiration reflect true re-employment or exits from the register.

title: An Anatomy of International Trade: Evidence from French Firms
author: Jonathan Eaton, Samuel Kortum, Francis Kramarz
target_context: This paper studies French manufacturing firms using firm-level sales in 1986 for 229,900 firms (34,035 exporters) across 113 destinations (including France). It examines export entry, sales distributions, and how firm efficiency, fixed entry costs, and bilateral trade barriers shape participation and sales, combining customs and administrative manufacturing data. The authors estimate a heterogeneous‑firms trade model (Melitz-style) by the method of simulated moments and run general‑equilibrium counterfactuals (e.g., lower trade barriers or entry costs) to quantify effects on firm sales, exits, and welfare.

title: Risk Matters: The Real Effects of Volatility Shocks
author: Jesús Fernández-Villaverde, Pablo A. Guerrón-Quintana, Juan Rubio-Ramírez, Martín Uribe
target_context: Study of how time-varying volatility of real interest rates affects real activity in four emerging small open economies (Argentina, Ecuador, Venezuela, Brazil) using monthly data roughly 1994–2008 (EMBI series from ~1997–2008 for most countries). title: A New Test of Borrowing Constraints for Education
author: Meta Brown, John Karl Scholz, Ananth Seshadri
target_context: This paper studies U.S. parent–child pairs (siblings) to test borrowing constraints for higher education, combining a theoretical model with empirical analysis using Health and Retirement Study cohorts (parents born c.1931–1947; children with median 18th birthday 1977) and NLSY‑97 validation. Empirical data span HRS waves 1992–2004 with post‑college cash transfers aggregated 1998–2004 and a 1994 retrospective module; institutional context is U.S. federal financial aid (FAFSA/EFC rules and the MISAA 1978 expansion). Unit of observation is children within families, exploiting sibling birth‑spacing to proxy variation in EFC.

title: Accounting for Incomplete Pass-Through
author: Emi Nakamura, Dawit Zerom
target_context: This paper studies incomplete pass-through of coffee commodity (green bean) costs to wholesale and retail ground-coffee prices in the United States using microdata on prices and sales across ~50 AC Nielsen markets and wholesale UPC-level data (1997–2005; retail demand estimation 2000–2004). Units include firms/brands (e.g., Folgers, Maxwell House), products and local markets. The institutional setting is an oligopolistic packaged-coffee industry with volatile international commodity prices; analyses exploit commodity price variation (and weather shocks in Brazil/Colombia) to identify cost-to-price pass-through and to estimate structural menu-cost pricing models.

title: Teacher Performance Pay: Experimental Evidence from India
author: Karthik Muralidharan, Venkatesh Sundararaman
target_context: This paper reports a randomized evaluation (2005–07) of teacher performance pay in rural Andhra Pradesh, India. The authors randomized 500 sampled government primary schools (focus on 300 schools: 100 group-incentive, 100 individual-incentive, 100 control) across 50 mandals, following baseline tests in June–July 2005 and endline tests in March–April 2006 and 2007. Units are pupils (grades 1–5), teachers, and schools. The intervention paid teacher bonuses (≈3% of annual pay) based on average student test-score improvements, in a setting with low learning, high teacher absence, and civil-service pay rules.

title: Macroeconomic Effects from Government Purchases and Taxes
author: Robert J. Barro, Charles J. Redlick
target_context: This paper uses U.S. annual national macro data (roughly 1912–2006, with main samples starting 1917/1930/1939/1950 and ending 2006) to estimate causal effects of government purchases—especially federal defense spending tied to WWI, WWII and the Korean War—and changes in average marginal income‑tax rates on per‑capita real GDP and its components. Units are national annual observations (per‑capita GDP, defense and non‑defense purchases, AMTR). Identification leverages war-driven exogenous variation, Ramey’s defense‑news, Romer‑Romer narrative tax shocks, and time‑series IV regressions.

title: Macroeconomic Effects from Government Purchases and Taxes
author: Robert J. Barro, Charles J. Redlick
target_context: Estimates refer to U.S. annual national per‑capita real GDP for a post‑1950 sample (1950–2006). title: Accountability and Flexibility in Public Schools: Evidence from Boston's Charters and Pilots
author: Atila Abdulkadiroglu, Joshua Angrist, Susan Dynarski, Thomas J. Kane, Parag Pathak
target_context: This paper evaluates the causal impact of attending Boston charter and pilot public schools using student-level administrative and MCAS test-score data from roughly 2001–2008. The unit of analysis is individual Boston Public School students (elementary, middle, and high school cohorts). The study exploits randomized admissions lotteries at over-subscribed charter and some pilot schools as a quasi-experiment, compares lottery-based IV estimates to observational regressions with baseline scores and demographics, and situates findings in Massachusetts’ charter/pilot institutional setting (union rules, charter caps).

title: Financing-Motivated Acquisitions
author: Isil Erel, Yeejin Jang, Michael S. Weisbach

title: As Certain as Debt and Taxes: Estimating the Tax Sensitivity of Leverage from Exogenous State Tax Changes
author: Florian Heider, Alexander Ljungqvist
target_context: Using firm-level panel data on publicly traded U.S. nonfinancial firms during 1990–2011, the paper exploits 121 staggered state corporate income tax changes—focusing here on tax increases—to identify effects on firms' long-term (book) leverage. Identification compares treated firms to same-industry control firms with industry-year fixed effects, includes firm- and state-level controls, neighbor-border comparisons, and treatment reversals, isolating the average response to a state corporate tax increase.

title: Agricultural Decisions after Relaxing Credit and Risk Constraints

target_context: This paper studies randomized field experiments conducted 2009–2011 in northern Ghana among smallholder maize farmers/households. title: Arbitrage Asymmetry and the Idiosyncratic Volatility Puzzle
author: Robert F. Stambaugh, Jianfeng Yu, Yu Yuan
target_context: This paper studies U.S. equity markets from August 1965 to January 2011, using individual common stocks and value-weighted portfolios to examine how idiosyncratic volatility relates to average returns. title: Do Acquisitions Relieve Target Firms' Financial Constraints?

author: Mary Amiti, David E. Weinstein
target_context: This paper analyzes matched bank–firm loan and firm balance-sheet data for listed Japanese nonfinancial firms and their lenders over 1990–2010. title: Drought of Opportunities: Contemporaneous and Long Term Impacts of Rainfall Shocks on Human Capital
author: Manisha Shah, Bryce Millett Steinberg
target_context: This empirical study uses variation in district-level monsoon rainfall (1975–2008) to estimate effects of productivity shocks on human capital in rural India. title: Measuring Uncertainty
author: Kyle Jurado, Sydney C. Ludvigson, Serena Ng
target_context: This paper estimates time-varying macroeconomic uncertainty in the United States using monthly macro and financial series (1960:01–2011:12) and a quarterly firm-level panel of 155 firms (1970:Q1–2011:Q2). Units include 132 macro series and 147 financial series as predictors and firm-level profit-growth observations. Using diffusion-index forecasts, latent factors, and stochastic-volatility models, the authors construct aggregate uncertainty measures and identify uncertainty shocks via VARs with recursive (Cholesky) ordering to study effects on industrial production, employment, and hours across major episodes (e.g., 1973–74, 1981–82, 2007–09).

title: The Geography of Development:  Evaluating Migration Restrictions and Coastal Flooding
author: Klaus Desmet, Dávid Krisztián Nagy, Esteban Rossi-Hansberg
target_context: The paper calibrates a dynamic spatial growth model to global data around 2000 (G-Econ, transport networks, Gallup World Poll) at 1°×1° grid-cell resolution and simulates centuries of evolution (up to ~600 years). Units are grid cells and countries (agents = workers/firms) whose location choices face trade costs, local amenities, innovation diffusion, and migration quotas. Using this calibrated framework the authors evaluate causal counterfactuals: relaxing international migration restrictions (partial to full liberalization) and coastal flooding scenarios (e.g., 1–6 meter sea-level rise) to quantify welfare and productivity impacts.

title: The Aggregate Implications of Regional Business Cycles

title: The Elusive Costs of Inflation: Price Dispersion during the U.S. Great Inflation
author: Emi Nakamura, Jón Steinsson, Patrick Sun, Daniel Villar
target_context: The paper examines U.S. consumer price microdata (monthly individual price quotes for products/outlets—Entry Level Items) over 1978–2014, extending BLS CPI micro-data back to cover the “Great Inflation” (late 1970s–early 1980s, peak ≈12% in 1980) and the subsequent disinflation. title: The Long-Run Effects of Childhood Insurance Coverage: Medicaid Implementation, Adult Health, and Labor Market Outcomes
author: Andrew Goodman-Bacon
target_context: This estimate exploits the original U.S. Medicaid rollout (state implementations 1966–1970) comparing birth cohorts born roughly 1936–1975, aggregated by birth state, birth year, and race. Adult mortality is measured as 20-year cumulative mortality (1980–1999), conditional on surviving to 1980. Identification predicts migration‑adjusted cumulative childhood Medicaid eligibility from cross‑state differences in pre‑Medicaid AFDC rates (categorical eligibility) and implements event‑study (leads/lags) and IV specifications; effects are concentrated for early childhood exposure (ages 0–10), particularly for whites.

title: Fintech, Regulatory Arbitrage, and the Rise of Shadow Banks
author: Greg Buchak, Gregor Matvos, Tomasz Piskorski, Amit Seru
target_context: This analysis examines U.S. conforming mortgage originations (Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac loan data) in the post‑crisis period, using individual loans as the unit of observation and comparing traditional banks, non‑fintech shadow lenders, and online fintech originators. title: Subsidizing Health Insurance for Low-Income Adults: Evidence from Massachusetts
author: Amy Finkelstein, Nathaniel Hendren, Mark Shepard
target_context: This paper studies Massachusetts' subsidized insurance exchange "CommCare" from 2009–2013, focusing on fiscal year 2011. It uses individual-level administrative enrollment, claims, and reported income (% of FPL) for non-elderly adults (ages 19–64) eligible between 135–300% of the federal poverty level who lacked employer or Medicaid coverage. CommCare's subsidy schedule produced discrete premium jumps at 150%, 200%, and 250% FPL (and an individual mandate with penalties); these institutional discontinuities identify causal effects of enrollee premiums on take-up, selection, and insurer costs.

title: Uncertainty Shocks as Second-Moment News Shocks
author: David Berger, Ian Dew-Becker, Stefano Giglio
target_context: Monthly U.S. aggregate data are analyzed (daily S&P 500 returns aggregated to months, option-implied volatilities from 1983 onward, macro series through the 2008 crisis and beyond). The unit is the aggregate stock market and macro aggregates (industrial production, employment, Fed funds rate). The paper contrasts realized volatility with forward-looking uncertainty (VIX-like measures), uses VAR-based news-shock identification and asset-pricing (variance-swap) evidence, and validates identification with simulated structural models featuring negatively skewed technology shocks.

title: The Welfare Effects of Encouraging Rural-Urban Migration
author: David Lagakos, Ahmed Mushfiq Mobarak, Michael E. Waugh
target_context: This paper studies rural–urban migration in northern Bangladesh using randomized migration-subsidy experiments conducted in the Rangpur region (notably a 2008 RCT with follow-ups and a larger 2014 replication). Units are poor, landless rural households observed around the lean-season (Monga); interventions were small travel subsidies (~800 Taka) encouraging seasonal migration. The authors combine RCT variation and national HIES data to estimate a dynamic incomplete-markets structural model of seasonal and permanent migration with seasonal income cycles, stochastic shocks, limited insurance, and migration disutility.

title: Sources of Displaced Workers’ Long-Term Earnings Losses
author: Marta Lachowska, Alexandre Mas, Stephen A. Woodbury
target_context: Using linked employer–employee UI records for Washington State (2002–2014), this paper examines long-tenure workers displaced during the Great Recession (separations mainly 2008–2010). The unit is individual workers observed quarterly (primary-employer earnings and hours); Washington’s UI data uniquely report quarterly paid hours. The analysis exploits mass-layoff timing and a comparison group of long-tenure non-displaced workers to identify causal effects of displacement on earnings, decomposing outcomes into hours, hourly wages, employer fixed effects, and worker–employer match effects.

title: Financial Heterogeneity and the Investment Channel of Monetary Policy
author: Pablo Ottonello, Thomas Winberry
target_context: The paper analyzes U.S. publicly listed firms using quarterly Compustat panels and high-frequency FOMC event shocks from January 1990–December 2007 to study how firm-level default risk (leverage, distance-to-default) alters investment responses to conventional monetary policy. The setting includes firm fixed effects, sector-by-quarter controls, and local-projection dynamics (up to three years) to trace causal investment responses across heterogeneous firms.

title: Uncertainty and Economic Activity: A Multi-Country Perspective

target_context: This paper analyzes quarterly country-level data on real GDP growth and realized equity-market volatility for 32 advanced and emerging economies (covering >90% of world GDP) over 1993:Q1–2011:Q2. title: Business Cycle Anatomy
author: George-Marios Angeletos, Fabrice Collard, Harris Dellas
target_context: This paper analyzes U.S. macroeconomic quarterly data (1955–2017) using a ten-variable VAR/VECM (unemployment, per-capita GDP, investment, consumption, hours, productivity measures, labor share, inflation, federal funds rate) to identify shocks operating at business-cycle (6–32 quarters) and long-run frequencies. The units are aggregate U.S. time series; the study examines pre/post‑Volcker and Great Recession/ZLB periods, evaluates frequency-domain SVAR “max-share” shocks, and uses Bayesian VAR estimation and medium-scale DSGE model simulations to assess propagation mechanisms.

title: Do You Know That I Know That You Know...? Higher-Order Beliefs in Survey Data
author: Olivier Coibion, Yuriy Gorodnichenko, Saten Kumar, Jane Ryngaert
target_context: This paper uses two survey waves of New Zealand firms (initial: 2017Q4–2018Q1, follow‑up: 2018Q1–2018Q2) with a fresh sample of 1,025 firm managers (≥6 employees) and 515 reinterviews three months later. Respondents across manufacturing, professional/financial services and other sectors received randomized information treatments (average first‑order beliefs, average higher‑order beliefs, both, or past inflation). The study measures causal effects of these RCT treatments on managers’ first‑ and higher‑order inflation expectations and, via IV and panel regressions, on firm decisions (employment, investment, prices, wages).

title: The Making of the Modern Metropolis: Evidence from London
author: Stephan Heblich, Stephen J. Redding, Daniel M. Sturm
target_context: Using newly constructed spatially disaggregated data for 1801–1921, this paper studies Greater London (parish and borough level) and its residents, workers and bilateral commuting flows to assess how the mid‑19th‑century steam railway revolution (first passenger line 1836) reorganized workplaces and residences. The setting features private, uncoordinated railway construction, low pre‑rail travel speeds, limited metropolitan planning (pre‑MBW/LCC), and administrative rateable land values; analyses use 1921 bilateral commuting as a baseline to recover historical employment and run counterfactuals.

target_context: Using newly constructed spatially disaggregated data for 1801–1921, this paper studies Greater London (parish and borough level) and its residents, workers and bilateral commuting flows to assess how the mid‑19th‑century steam railway revolution (first passenger line 1836) reorganized workplaces and residences. The setting features private, uncoordinated railway construction, low pre‑rail travel speeds, limited metropolitan planning (pre‑MBW/LCC), and administrative rateable land values; analyses use 1921 bilateral commuting as a baseline to recover historical employment and run counterfactuals.

title: Mortgage Prepayment and Path-Dependent Effects of Monetary Policy
author: David W. Berger, Konstantin Milbradt, Fabrice Tourre, Joseph Vavra
target_context: This paper studies US fixed‑rate, prepayable mortgage markets and monetary transmission over 1992–2017 using loan‑level servicing data (BKFS McDash) and linked Equifax borrower records (CRISM). The setting is the US mortgage/financial intermediation system and Fed policy driving short‑term rates and mortgage rate pass‑through, including pre‑ and post‑Great‑Recession low‑rate periods that shape refinancing incentives and regional spending (e.g., auto purchases).

title: Inflation Expectations and Firm Decisions: New Causal Evidence
author: Olivier Coibion, Yuriy Gorodnichenko, Tiziano Ropele
target_context: Using the Bank of Italy quarterly Survey on Inflation and Growth Expectations (SIGE) and linked administrative data (CCR, INPS, CADS), the paper studies a panel of Italian non-financial firms (50+ employees) from 2012 onward (treatment introduced in 2012Q3; ELB-focused subperiod 2014Q4–2018Q2). title: Consumer Spending During Unemployment: Positive and Normative Implications
author: Peter Ganong, Pascal J. Noel
target_context: Using de-identified JPMorgan Chase monthly bank-account data from January 2014–June 2016 across 20 U.S. states, the paper studies roughly 182,000 households who received unemployment insurance (UI) by direct deposit. It exploits variation in UI generosity, timing, and duration (most states six months; e.g., Florida four months, New Jersey unusually generous and no waiting period) to trace high-frequency household income, nondurable spending categories, and job‑finding hazards around UI receipt and predictable benefit exhaustion.

title: On the Direct and Indirect Real Effects of Credit Supply Shocks
author: Laura Alfaro, Manuel García-Santana, Enrique Moral-Benito
target_context: The paper studies bank lending supply shocks and their propagation through buyer–supplier networks in Spain using administrative firm-level and matched bank–firm loan data (Spanish Credit Registry) for 2003–2013. Units are firms (≈1.8M) and banks (≈235); authors construct year-by-year bank–year supply shocks via matched employer–employee high-dimensional fixed effects and combine firm balance sheets with 2010 input–output tables to measure downstream/upstream exposure. They analyze direct and indirect effects on employment, output and investment across 2003–2007 (expansion), 2008–2009 (financial crisis) and 2010–2013 (recession).

title: Monetary Policy Communications and their Effects on Household Inflation Expectations
author: Olivier Coibion, Yuriy Gorodnichenko, Michael Weber
target_context: Using a large randomized information experiment fielded to ~20,000 U.S. households in the Kilts-Nielsen Homescan panel (waves in June, September, and December 2018), the paper studies how different communications—e.g., 12-month CPI, the Fed’s 2% target, FOMC forecasts/statements, a USA Today article, gasoline/unemployment facts, and a placebo—affect 12-month inflation expectations and subsequent household spending. Outcomes combine survey responses and high-frequency Nielsen scanner purchase data in a low-inflation U.S. monetary policy environment with three- and six-month follow-ups.

title: Judging Judge Fixed Effects
author: Brigham R. Frandsen, Lars J. Lefgren, Emily C. Leslie
target_context: The paper develops a test of identifying assumptions for judge fixed-effects instrumental-variable designs and applies it to criminal cases in Miami-Dade County (2006–2014). The unit is defendants at weekend bail hearings, where rotating assignment creates variation in bail-judge leniency; treatment is pretrial release (release within three days) and the primary outcome is conviction. The setting uses leave-out mean judge leniency instruments, examines exclusion/monotonicity assumptions, and complements empirical IV estimates with simulations and subgroup first-stage checks.

title: Migration and Informal Insurance: Evidence from a Randomized Controlled Trial and a Structural Model
author: Costas Meghir, Ahmed Mushfiq Mobarak, Corina D. Mommaerts, Melanie Morten
target_context: This paper studies a village-level randomized subsidy experiment in northern Bangladesh that offered 600 Taka (~USD 8.50) transport subsidies in August–September 2008 for temporary seasonal migration during the Monga lean season. The analysis uses eligible poor rural households (low landholdings, reported skipping meals) surveyed pre-intervention (2008), during 2008–09, and in a longer-run follow-up in 2011 (and some 2013 data). The setting examines spillovers of migration incentives on informal village risk-sharing and welfare, and combines RCT variation with a structural model estimation.

title: Misallocation Under Trade Liberalization
author: Yan Bai, Keyu Jin, Dan Lu
target_context: This paper develops a heterogeneous-firm trade model with firm-level distortions and structurally estimates it using Chinese manufacturing microdata (annual firm surveys for 1998–2007, emphasizing 2005) to quantify welfare effects of trade liberalization associated with China’s early-2000s opening to trade. target_context: This paper studies U.S. postwar business cycles using annual sector-level data for 37 private nonfarm sectors from 1948–2018. title: Reserve Accumulation, Macroeconomic Stabilization, and Sovereign Risk
author: Javier Bianchi, César Sosa-Padilla
target_context: This paper studies international reserve accumulation in emerging market countries over roughly 1990–2015, combining a sovereign-default model with empirical analysis on a panel of 22 emerging economies (country-year units). Empirical tests relate reserves/GDP, debt/GDP, sovereign spreads and a 3‑year rolling measure of exchange‑rate variability, and examine crisis episodes (notably 2008). The institutional setting contrasts fixed vs. flexible exchange‑rate regimes, long‑term foreign currency debt, downward nominal wage rigidities, and global risk‑premium shocks as drivers of portfolio and stabilization policies.

title: Fintech Borrowers: Lax-Screening or Cream-Skimming?
author: Marco Di Maggio, Vincent Yao
target_context: Using individual-level monthly credit-bureau data from the U.S. (2012–2017), this study compares unsecured personal loans originated by online fintech firms and traditional lenders. The unit is the loan/borrower (monthly panel spanning 3 months pre- to 15 months post-origination) across U.S. zip codes and states. Fintechs are defined as non-deposit, online-only, recently founded lenders; the institutional background includes rising fintech market share and regulation primarily by state regulators/CFPB. Analyses exploit local time variation and lender switching to infer causal effects on defaults, balances, and pricing.

title: The Supply-Side Effects of Monetary Policy
author: David Baqaee, Emmanuel Farhi, Kunal Sangani
target_context: The paper examines how monetary policy shocks change aggregate TFP and resource allocation by reallocating inputs across heterogeneous firms. Empirical analyses use identified monetary shocks (Romer and Romer; high-frequency shocks) in U.S. time-series and panel contexts, and firm-level data (Compustat for U.S. public firms; Belgian firm-level pass-through estimates) across industries and years. Units are the aggregate economy and firms. The setting emphasizes nominal rigidities (Calvo/menu costs), heterogeneous markups and pass-throughs, and monetary and discount-factor shocks as exogenous demand disturbances.

title: The Effect of Macroeconomic Uncertainty on Firm Decisions

target_context: Using two survey waves in New Zealand (first wave June–Oct 2021, follow-up Nov 2021–Feb 2022), the authors survey ~4,000 firms (about 2,000 reinterviewed) employing ≥6 workers.
